fullProgramDescription: The Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering program at Stanford University aims to develop a broad foundation in mechanical engineering principles, as well as the skills to apply these principles to real-world problems. The program covers topics such as mechanics, thermodynamics, materials science, and mechanical design, providing a strong grounding for a variety of careers or further study.
shortProgramDescription: Stanford's Mechanical Engineering B.S. provides a comprehensive education in mechanical engineering fundamentals, preparing students for diverse careers or further study.
classHighlights: Mechanics and Materials: Courses cover statics (ME69), dynamics (ME70), mechanics of solids and fluids (ME301, ME341), and materials science (MATSCI105). Students develop a deep understanding of mechanical principles and material properties.
Thermodynamics and Energy: Courses include thermodynamics (ME100), heat transfer (ME111), and energy systems (ME101), providing a comprehensive understanding of energy conversion and transfer.
Mechanical Design and Systems: Students learn mechanical design principles (ME101B, ME102B), systems dynamics, and control systems (ME102, ME106), and apply these to real-world problems.
Mathematics and Science: The program requires a strong foundation in mathematics (including differential equations and linear algebra) and science (physics, chemistry).

Laboratory and Computational Courses: Practical laboratory and computational courses, such as ME111, ME106, and ME301, help students apply theoretical concepts to experimental and computational problems.
Engineering Fundamentals: Students complete foundational engineering courses, including ENGR40M (electronics) or ENGR76 (intro to engineering) and ENGR108 (intro to signals and systems).
Technical Electives: Students choose from a range of technical electives to explore specialized areas within mechanical engineering, such as biomechanical engineering, energy systems, or robotics.
learningOutcomes: Apply fundamental principles of mechanical engineering to analyze and design mechanical systems.
Understand and apply knowledge of mechanics, thermodynamics, and materials science.
Design and conduct experiments, as well as analyze and interpret data.
Use mathematical and computational tools to model and simulate mechanical systems.
Communicate complex technical information effectively in written and oral forms.
Work effectively in teams to design, develop, and test mechanical systems.
Consider ethical, societal, and environmental implications of mechanical engineering designs and practices.
creditRequirements: At least 180 quarter units, including major requirements and technical electives, with a minimum of 96 units in the major
additionalInformation: Students must declare the major through the School of Engineering; AP/IB credits may be applied towards certain requirements with departmental approval.
